As it is said in various sÅ«tras, the World-Honored One spoke of three kinds of karma, namely, bodily karma, verbal karma, and mental karma.

Among them, some say that because it is created by the body, it is called bodily karma. Because speech itself is karma, it is called verbal karma. Both of these take both revealing and non-revealing [karma] as their intrinsic nature.
Because it is karma associated with the mind, it is called mental karma. This karma is only by its intrinsic nature of volition.
What dharma is called revealing [karma] here?
First, bodily revealing karma takes shape and color as its nature. It is born from the mind that takes this as its object.
Whose shape and color? It means the shape and color of the body.
If it is the shape and color of the body, why was it said earlier that because it is created by the body, it is called bodily karma?
It means because it is included in one part of the body as a whole, it is called the shape and color of the body.
Because it arises in dependence on the great elements of the body, it is called created by the body.
When speaking of the body as a whole, it also applies to the individual parts, just as the world says that one dwells in a town or in a forest.
Why is it also said that the mind, etc., that arises taking this as its object?

In order to distinguish it from the shape and color of the lips, etc., which are not produced by the mind, etc., that takes them as its object, because it is produced by the mind, etc., that takes sound as its object.

It is also in order to distinguish it from the shape and color that is attracted by the mind, etc., of a previous vow, which is not produced by the mind, etc., that takes it as its object, because it is produced by the mind, etc., that is the cause of retribution for something else.
Why is it called indication?
Because it can indicate the mind that produces its own action and cause others to know it.
In order to show this meaning, a verse is spoken:
By externally emitting body and speech, it indicates the thought that arises internally in the mind,
Just like a fish hidden in the deep water, it beats the waves and indicates itself.
What is shape and color?
It refers to the nature of long, etc.
What is long, etc.?
It refers to the names and concepts of long, etc., that arise in relation to it.
In which category is this included?
It is included in the sense field of form.
Now we should consider:
Are length, etc. distinctions of atoms, like visible form?
Or are they accumulations of distinctions of atoms?
Or is it a separate entity that pervades aggregates such as form, etc.?
If so, what is wrong?
If length, etc. were distinctions of atoms, then in each subtle part of a mass of form, length, etc. could be apprehended, just as with visible form.
If they were accumulations of distinctions of atoms, what would be the difference between them and the accumulation of atoms of visible form?
The distinction of the accumulation of visible form itself should be length, etc.
If it is a separate entity that pervades aggregates such as form, etc., then because it is unitary and pervasive, it should be wholly apprehensible in each part, because it exists in all parts;
or it should not be unitary, because it abides separately in the parts.
Moreover, it contradicts one's own doctrine that the ten bases are all accumulations of atoms.
Moreover, one should support the doctrine of the VaibhÄá¹£ikas of KaÅ›mÄ«r, because they hold that real unities pervade their parts.

In the case of all the various colors that are combined, when one side is seen to be long, one produces the notion of long. When one side is seen to be short, one produces the notion of short. When the four sides are seen to be equal, one produces the notion of square. When all the sides are seen to be full, one produces the notion of round. When the center is seen to be convex, one produces the notion of high. When the center is seen to be concave, one produces the notion of low. When the sides are seen to be even, one produces the notion of correct. When the sides are seen to be uneven, one produces the notion of incorrect. When one sees a spinning wheel or brocade, one produces various notions of different forms. But there should not really be different kinds of colored forms existing in the same place, like the various colors.
If one admits this, then one should produce all notions of form in regard to each individual place.

But this is not the case. Therefore form does not have a separate substance. It is just the various colors that, when arranged differently in the various directions, produce the notions of long, etc., just as there is no error in the case of trees, ants, etc., being arranged in a line.
If this is so, then how is it that when one is far away or in the dark, one does not perceive the colors but perceives the form?
How can one perceive the shape of a row without perceiving the shape of the trees?

However, apart from the trees there is no separate row. Or, in the case of distant or dark masses of color, if the manifestation or shape cannot be perceived, although one is able to grasp it, it is not clear, and one doubts what it is or what one is seeing.
Therefore, one should know that one only grasps manifest color. Because of distance and darkness, one sees unclearly. Therefore, the theory that indication is shape is not established.
Some say:
Bodily indication has movement as its nature. It is produced by mind and so forth, taking this as its object.
Why is it also said that it is produced by mind and so forth, taking this as its object?

In order to distinguish it from the trembling of the lips and so forth, which is not produced by mind and so forth taking that as an object, because it is produced by mind and so forth taking speech as an object.
What is called movement?
It is called moving to another place.
In which category is this included?
It is included in the category of form.
How is it known that this moves to another place?
Because the specific characteristics cannot be known.

This reasoning is not correct. It is like a cooked object. Although when it is just touched by fire, light, snow, vinegar, and other conditions of cooking, there are differences, but their specific characteristics cannot be known.
However, there are differences between them before and after. This should also be so.
It is like a long piece of firewood or grass. Although the flames produced by each part are different due to their similarities, their specific characteristics cannot be known.
However, there are differences between those parts. This should also be so.
If the characteristics of cooking of a cooked object do not arise immediately when it is just touched by conditions, they should also not arise later, because the conditions are no different.

If the parts of a long piece of firewood or grass are similar and the flames do not arise separately in each part, then those flames should not exist, because they are different in shape, size, illumination, and the differences of flames and heat.

Therefore, you should not say that because the specific characteristics of the transformation are not known, it is the same dharma that moves to another place. You should carefully understand the specific characteristics of that transformation.
If you say that because the cause of cessation cannot be obtained, you know that it is the same dharma that moves to another place,
this is also unreasonable. What is the cause of cessation of mind, mental factors, sound, flame, etc.? Why do they cease moment by moment?
The cessation of other dharmas should also be like this, not dependent on a cause.
If you say that mind, etc. also have a cause of cessation, namely, the specific impermanence of each,
why is this not so for other dharmas?
If other dharmas are not like this, why is this so for mind, etc.?
Therefore, you should know that the cessation of mind, etc. does not depend on a cause.
If mind, etc. are like this, other dharmas should also be like this.
If the cessation of other dharmas does not depend on a cause, then before fuel, etc. have combined with fire, etc., the nature of form, etc. should not be apprehensible.
Like the state after combination, the state after should also be like the state before, and apprehensible.
How is it that before the wind or the hand touches the lamp or the clapper, the flame and the sound are clearly perceived, but not after?
But the flame and the sound are extinguished without the wind or the hand, and the same is true of fuel, etc. This should not be a problem.

Moreover, if fuel, etc., are extinguished by fire, etc., and their form, etc., cannot be perceived, they should not be perceptible immediately after contact, because they have a difference at the time of contact, and because there is no difference in external conditions.

When the characteristics of various cooked things, such as rice, etc., arise in different degrees, such as inferior, medium, and superior, due to those as causes, the later ones arise and the earlier ones cease.
What is the cause of this?

It should not be that this dharma arises due to that, and then this again ceases due to that dharma. Two mutually contradictory dharmas are not produced by the same cause, as is well established in the world.
Therefore conditioned dharmas do not depend on a cause of cessation, but cease by themselves.

As for the previously mentioned that which can be grasped and that which cannot be grasped, you should know that the characteristics of the continuity, following, cessation, and destruction are slightly increased.
Moreover, if the dharma of cessation also has a cause, then there should be no cessation without a cause.
Just as mind and mental factors depend on causes to arise, cessation should also be like this. Apart from mind, etc., there is no impermanence established by the world.
Moreover, because the causes are different, cessation should be distinguished, just as cooking is distinguished because of the differences of fire, light, snow, vinegar, etc.
Moreover, a dharma that has already ceased should be able to cease again, because it is accepted as having a cause, just like form, etc.
Therefore, the dharma of cessation definitely has no cause.
Because cessation has no cause, it ceases as soon as it arises. Therefore, we know that there is no transference to another place.
If it is said that because the cause of arising cannot be obtained, we know that this very dharma transfers to another place,

This is also unreasonable, because there is a cause of birth, that is, the prior causes the birth of the subsequent. For example, the prior moment of mind causes the birth of the subsequent moment of mind, prior ripening causes subsequent ripening, milk causes cheese, grape juice causes wine, and wine causes vinegar, etc. Therefore, there is no dharma that moves to another place.
Since there is no movement, how can there be action?
Moreover, if there is abiding, there is no movement. Since there is no movement, it should be permanently abiding.
If dharmas have no abiding, there is also no movement, because as soon as they are born they perish and have no meaning of movement.
If that is so, why do we see movement?
What is seen in another place is not the original thing.
How do we know that what is seen is not the original thing?
Because it is newly born in each place.

Like a flame or a shadow, it does not move from one place to another. A shadow is not seen in another place when the object is not moving. The light of the sun and so on is far or near, and when it turns, one sees the shadow either long or short or moving.
Moreover, because it obstructs light to some extent.
There is a question:
Why is it necessary to question the meaning of reaching another place?
How do you know that what is seen in another place is not the original object?
This should also cite the previous principle as evidence, namely, if there is abiding, then there is no movement and so on.
Moreover, the conditions of external fire and so on are without distinction, yet at a later time, distinction can be grasped. By this, it is proven that each moment is separate.
Moreover, if it is said that what is seen elsewhere is still the original object because the cause of difference is absent,
since there is no cause to prove that it is the original object, why not say that it is not the original object?
Because of these two meanings, both should be uncertain, so the meaning of reaching another place is not established.
The sun-rising theorist makes this statement:
In reality, there is no meaning of dharmas arriving at other places, because the nature of conditioned dharmas is to cease moment by moment.
However, there is a separate dharma whose cause is the mind's distinctions. Based on hands, feet, etc., this dharma can make the hands, feet, etc.
The cause for the arising of things in different places is called movement, and it is also called bodily expression.
In which category is this included?
It is included in the form aggregate.
If so, why not allow that it is seen like all visible forms?
Since it is neither seen nor indicates to others, how can it be called indication?
Moreover, how do we know that this dharma really exists?
How can this dharma cause one's own body to move to other places and arise differently?
If it is said that it is due to the distinctions of the mind, then the wind element that arises should be like this.
The nature of the wind element is movement, and it is sufficient as the cause for arising in different places.
Why, apart from the wind, grasp at a dharma of movement?
Moreover, grass, leaves, etc., apart from the external wind element, have no separate dharma of movement. How do they move?

However, the nature of the wind element that produces the tactile sensations of shaking, etc., is to move, and it should be admitted that it can cause the hand, etc., to move and be born in another place. What need is there to grasp separately?
If the substance and function of the dharma that can move are not established,
if it is not so, then the wind element produced by the distinctions of mind can be the cause for the birth of the hand, etc., in another place, and it should be bodily expression.
In this way, the wind element does not indicate anything, so how can it be called expression?
Moreover, if it is admitted that the category of touch is good or bad, one is not a disciple of ÅšÄkyamuni.
If it is not so, then the distinctions of mind can cause one's own body to be born in another place, and the arising of the body should be bodily expression.
In this case, bodily expression should be conventionally existent and not real, because the essence of one's own body is a combination of many dharmas.
Moreover, it does not indicate anything, so how can it be called expression?
Because smell, etc., cannot indicate to others.
Moreover, if it is admitted that smell, etc., is good or bad, one is not a disciple of ÅšÄkyamuni.

If this were not so, then the visible form produced by the mindâ€™s special power would be bodily intimation, but visible form is not produced by the mindâ€™s special power, because it is produced by the special power of its own seeds and the wind.
Also, if you admit that visible form is good or bad, then you are not a Buddhist.
If this visible form is not bodily intimation by nature, then that which arises elsewhere would be bodily intimation.
O friend, let us grant you the freedom to think about this intimation as much as you can, but it cannot be accomplished by effort. Why do you tire yourself in vain?
Who can establish that arising has a separate substance?
This arising that you hold to is not directly perceived like form, etc., nor is it the direct perceiver like the eye, etc. How do you know that it exists?
Also, if it is not visible, how can it be called intimation?
It was previously said that it cannot indicate to others.
Also, if visible form is good or bad, then you can say that this arising is bodily intimation.
However, the visible form of the primary elements is neither good nor bad, as has already been explained.
The same should be true of the primary elements that are born. Therefore, there definitely is no real bodily informative action.
If this is so, then bodily action should be only noninformative.
What is the meaning of the term noninformative?
It means the form that is included in the factor element.ğŸ”½How can there be good noninformative action in the realm of desire that is produced apart from information?
If there is noninformative action in the realm of desire, what error ensues?
It would follow that it would be like that in the realm of form and would follow the mind.
Then, in the case of other minds and in the mindless samÄdhi, there would be neither morality nor immorality.

If you claim that there is no error because one promises to speak when one receives the precepts, then when one is silent and does not speak at the time of reciting the precepts, one does not make a promise. How does one come to have the sin of lying?
Also, there would be no nondetermined bodily action, because noninformative action is of only two kinds.
Also, there would be no good or bad bodily action for even a single moment, because all unmanifest action would definitely continue in a series.

This means that if a light mind does not issue unmanifest action, that issued by a heavy mind will definitely continue in a series. Even though they imagine that there is bodily and vocal action that is form, it cannot be good or bad.
Why is this?
They say that form and action are all necessarily abandoned at the moment of death. How can one obtain a desirable or undesirable result in the future on the basis of this?
There are those who say,
Why is this unreasonable?
This means that past action really exists, because it can obtain a future result that it has attracted.

This is like a boil on top of a boil, because you grasp the real existence of the substance of past action. If it existed previously and later does not exist, it is called past. How can you grasp it as really existing?
If this is so, why did the World Honored One himself say,
â€œEven though action passes through a hundred eons, in the end it is not lost.
When encountering the convergence of various conditions, it is certain that [the effect] will repay that [cause].
What meaning is revealed by the words without loss?
It reveals the meaning that the karma that is performed is not without effect. This meaning is established by the latter half of the verse.
Who would not believe and accept that good and bad karma, even after a long time, can obtain a result?
One should only contemplate how the result is obtained.
Is it obtained by the transformation and distinction of the continuity, like rice seeds and so forth?
Or is it obtained by the enduring without destruction for a long time of its own characteristics?
If the result is obtained by the transformation and distinction of the continuity, the meaning is acceptable.

If the result is obtained by the enduring without destruction for a long time of its own characteristics, it should be said that this karma, enduring for a long time without ceasing, is able to obtain a result.

If you say that this action is not called extinguished because it does not exist by intrinsic nature, but rather that it is called extinguished because it no longer has any function, how is it that this action no longer has any function?
Because it can no longer attract a future result.
Why can it no longer attract a future result?
Because it has already attracted that result.
One cannot attract a result and then attract it again, just as a dharma that has already been produced cannot be produced again.
Why does it not attract other results that are similar?
Because there is no limit to the number of results that are similar. But isnâ€™t it true that this result also exists in the present?

Because it has already been attracted, it does not need to be attracted again. The substance of the action does not perish and should always be present. Why does it not always attract the result that it obtains?

Isnâ€™t it true that we have already said that one cannot attract a result and then attract it again, just as a dharma that has already been produced cannot be produced again? Why do you raise this question again?
Even though we have already said this, we have not yet resolved this difficulty.
If the substance of the action always exists, it should be like the middle term and always be called present.
It should always be able to attract a result, and it should be able to produce a result at the beginning and at the end.
If you say that the substance of past action exists but does not have activity and therefore is not present, and because it is not present it cannot attract a result,
this is also not reasonable, because if it always has substance, it should be like the present and always have activity.
Also, if you maintain that past dharmas have the function of giving a result, how can they not be present?

If you say that the present is so called because it is the function of dharmas in taking a result, this is not reasonable, because the meaning of function is the same as the meaning of result and they should both be present.

Past dharmas do not have the function of taking a result and are called past. Those that have the function of giving a result should be called present. When this function ends, it should be called extinction. This means that dharmas that have already perished perish again. In this way, they should be born again after having been born. Therefore the meaning of this school is not established.
Also, how do you say that dharmas can attract results?
It means that they establish the future birth of the result.
Those who have exhausted the contaminants should not induce effects in their final moment, because they will not be reborn afterwards.

If the last moment of consciousness of one whose contaminants have been extinguished does not produce a result, then it would not be the present, and it would not be necessary for it to enter the past.ğŸ”½If it is not present, how can it be said to have already ceased and entered the past?
If it is present but has no function, how can it be said to have already ceased?
If it is necessary for it to cease even though it has already ceased, then it would be necessary for it to be born even though it has already been born. This would contradict your previous statement.
If you claim that even though this moment of consciousness has the function of producing a subsequent result, the subsequent result is not produced because the conditions are lacking,
this is also unreasonable. If the result definitely will not be produced, how can you know that there is a function of producing it?

We reply, this moment of consciousness is either present or absent in the two conditions of opposition and conformity. Even though it is born from a cause, it has no function of producing a subsequent result.
Therefore, the meaning of the ability to project a result in this kind of case is definitely not established in the SÄá¹ƒkhya theory.
Therefore, it is only because it nourishes the seeds of the effect that it is said to be able to project the effect.
Also, that school maintains that the substance of past and future exist in reality. Why is it that the future does not project its effect in the same way as the present?
If all things exist at all times, what time and what thing is not existent?
A scripture says,
When it encounters the convergence of conditions, it will repay that effect.
Also, they should explain who has the ability to establish what, and why it is said that it is called the ability to project the effect because it establishes that which is to be born.

Because all things exist at all times, therefore the statement that past action, whose substance exists in reality, is able to obtain the effect that it attracts in the future is definitely not reasonable.

In that case, you must admit that there is a real production of a dharma in the continuity of aggregates that is projected by good and bad actions of body and speech, and that this dharma is categorized as a real dharma that is neither form nor consciousness.
Some say that this dharma is called growth.
Some say that this dharma is called nonloss, because it can obtain the future results of good and bad actions.
Mental action should also be admitted to have this dharma, otherwise it would be annihilated when another mind arises.
If a dharma of this kind is not produced in the continuity of a mind, how can it obtain the results of future lives?
Therefore it must be admitted that this dharma exists.
If one recites and memorizes texts and their meanings at one time, and later after a long time one again produces memory,

and if one often sees, hears, etc., various objects at one time, and later after a long time one again produces memory of those objects, what dharma is produced in what moment, and because of this one later again produces memory?
Also, what dharma is produced by the mind that first enters into samÄdhi, etc., and because of this one later again produces the mind that emerges from samÄdhi?
Also, what dharma is produced by the simultaneous destruction of the madder dye and the jasmine flower, and later when the fruit ripens, the pulp is produced with a red color?

Therefore, apart from the dharmas of body and speech that are attracted by thought, we should only say that the power of thought perfuming the continuity of mind produces a capability. By the transformation of this capability, the differences of future results are born.

It is like the case of the juice of the madder plant dyeing the flower of the oleander, and the continuity being transformed until the time of the fruit, when the interior becomes red. The perfuming of internal dharmas should be understood in the same way.
Also, why do you not admit that the dharmas of body and speech perfume the continuity of mind?
Because the dharmas of body and speech are made good or bad by mind.

It is not proper to say that they are made good or bad by mind, and that they are able to give rise to a future loved or unloved result in a different continuity, because one does not create actions and another experiences the results.

If it is the case that even though the substance of the action has perished, by the power of the perfumed continuity of mind, a transformation of the differences is able to obtain a future loved result, etc., what about the case of the samÄdhi of cessation and the continuity of mind being cut off in the heavens of nonthought? How can previous actions obtain a future loved or unloved result?
There is an interpretation by Sthiramati that
in this life the mind perfumed previously must still continue in a series, and therefore one obtains in the future the results of good and bad action.
Since it has already been interrupted, what is the cause that can continue it?
The mind that enters samÄdhi acts as the similar and immediately antecedent condition and can cause it to continue.
How can it act as the similar and immediately antecedent condition when it has long since perished?
Just as past action is said to be able to obtain a result, this is the same and should be refuted in the same way. Therefore the mind that emerges from samÄdhi does not arise in a continuous series.
There is an interpretation by DharmapÄla that

the mind arises again later because of the power of seeds attached to material organs, because the seeds that generate mind and mental activities are attached to two kinds of continuities, i.e., the continuity of mind and the continuity of material organs, as the case may be.
Isnâ€™t it said in the scriptures that
mind and its activities are born from the conditions of mind and dharmas?
How can mind and mental activities be born apart from mind?

You must understand that the seeds of mind are sometimes called mind, because the name of the result is sometimes given to the cause, just as the name hunger and thirst is given to the external condition of contact.
How does each mind and mental factor arise from a continuum of two seeds?
We do not see such a thing in the case of sprouts, etc., arising from seeds. It is possible that many conditions produce one effect.
There is no arising of one effect from two seeds.
If this is so, then you still cannot avoid the previous error.
That is, if the mind continuum is severed in the attainment of non-thought and non-discrimination, how can previous karma obtain a future loved or unloved effect?
This is an error of your school.
What do you mean by your school?
It means those who hold that this state is completely devoid of mind.
If you say that this state has mind, then there is no error.
As stated in the Treatise on Questions Composed by Venerable Vasumitra:
If it is held that the attainment of cessation is completely devoid of mind, then this error would exist.
I say that the attainment of cessation still has subtle mind, so this error does not exist.
They further cite a sutra to prove this meaning, as stated in the sutra:
In the state of cessation of ideation and feeling, bodily activity is all extinguished, and so on up to the faculties are not destroyed.
Consciousness does not leave the body. What consciousness is there in this state?
Some say
that there is sixth consciousness, i.e., mental consciousness.
Is it not said in the scriptures that
mind and dharmas are the conditions that generate mental consciousness, and the union of the three is contact, which arises simultaneously with feeling, conceptualization, and volition?
How can this state have mental consciousness but not the union of the three, or have the union of the three but not contact, or have contact but not feeling and conceptualization?
This is why it is called the samÄdhi of the cessation of feeling and conceptualization.
There is an interpretation by Sthiramati that
how can the World Honored One have said that feeling is the condition of craving, and yet not all feeling is a condition of craving?
Contact is also like this. Not all contact is a condition of feeling, etc.
The World Honored One himself has explained this in other scriptures, where he says that feeling that is born of contact associated with ignorance produces craving.
There is no place where it is said that contact produces feeling, and since there is no distinction made, this is not a good explanation.
There is another explanation.
The three things of contact are the three things of faculty, object, and consciousness, because they are powerful and united, contact arises.
In this state, the three things are not powerful enough to produce contact or feeling and conceptualization, because the mind of entry into samÄdhi is disgusted and destroyed.
While one is in samÄdhi, there is no contact, much less feeling and conceptualization. Therefore in this state only mental consciousness remains, and there are no mental activities.
If this is so, what is the mental consciousness in this state?
Is it good, impure, or indeterminate?
What is wrong with this?
If it is good, how can it be good in essence and not associated with the roots of goodness such as absence of craving?
If it is associated with the roots of goodness such as absence of craving, how can it be without contact?

If it is said that this consciousness is good because it is attracted by the immediately antecedent condition of good , this is not reasonable, because three kinds of consciousnesses, good, etc., are born immediately after a good mind.
Also, the good mind that is attracted by the power of the roots of good is incapable of being obstructed by anything, because it is free from craving, etc.
Also, if it is not a root of good, it should not be good.
However, this samÄdhi of cessation is good, just as cessation is good.ğŸ”½If its nature is that of impurity, how can it be associated with passions such as craving?
Even if it is associated with passions such as craving, how can it be without contact?
The Buddha himself said in the DaÅ›ottara SÅ«tra,
All aggregates of sensation, conceptualization, and the volitional predispositions have contact as their condition.
Also, we do not even admit that the samÄdhi of nonconceptualization is impure, much less the samÄdhi of cessation.
If its nature is that of indeterminate and unobscured, is it born of retribution, a comportment, a skill, or a transformation?
What is wrong with these alternatives?

If it is born of retribution, how can it be that the mind of the summit of existence is immediately followed by a mind born of retribution in the desire realm, which is far removed from the summit of existence in the eight stages?
How then can the mind of unmoving, etc., arise immediately after this mind?
As the MahÄkuÅ›ala-mÅ«la-tantra SÅ«tra asks:
When emerging from the concentration of cessation, how many contacts does one touch?
The answer says:
Venerable!
One touches three contacts, namely the contact of unmoving, the contact of nothingness, and the contact of signlessness.
Moreover, the mind of retribution is attracted by past karma. What reason is there for this?
By the power of the vow before entering the concentration of cessation, the time of emerging from concentration is not exceeded.
What is the reason for this?

Only at the edge of the mind of concentration on the peak of existence, taking cessation as its object, can the mind of retribution attracted by the habitual tendencies of past karma in the desire realm appear. It cannot appear in previous stages.
What is the reason for this?
The matter born of retribution that arises here is cut off and does not continue. The mind born of retribution is cut off but continues again.
If it is a path of deportment, a place of craftsmanship, or a place of transformation, how can this mind, without contact, create something?
Moreover, it is accepted that the nine successive concentrations and the eight liberations cultivated are all good. It should not be that a defiled or indeterminate mind appears in this state.
Moreover, using the peak of existence as the object of cessation, with tranquil thought as the basis, one is able to manifest entry into the concentration of cessation of ideation and sensation.
As in the MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila SÅ«tra, it is asked regarding the concentration of cessation:
How many causes and conditions are relied upon to enter the concentration of the formless realm?ğŸ”½The answer is:
Venerable!
Two causes and two conditions are relied upon to enter the concentration of the formless realm, namely, not contemplating any characteristics and correctly contemplating the formless realm.
If there is mental consciousness in the concentration of cessation, what object does it take?
What mode of activity does it have?
If it takes cessation as its object and has the aspect of quiescence, how is it not good?
If it is good, how can you not admit that it is associated with the roots of goodness such as noncovetousness?
If you admit that it is associated with these roots, how can you not admit that contact is its cause?
If it takes other objects and has other aspects, how can a distracted mind arise immediately after the mind that enters samÄdhi? How is this not contrary to reason?
Even if you imagine that it is indeterminate, this is not reasonable because of the above two reasons.

Therefore you do not understand the meaning of the scriptures. You imagine that the sixth mental consciousness exists in samÄdhi, etc., and on this basis you maintain that there is mind in these states.
If this is so, how can you admit that there is mind in the various states of unconsciousness, such as samÄdhi, etc.?

The subtle mind that exists in this state is accepted by those who take the sutras as their authority. That is, the consciousness that is retribution is endowed with all seeds and, from the moment of reentry into a new rebirth until the moment of death, it continues in a series without a break. In the various destinies, it evolves through the power of the cause of retribution and the differences of the various kinds of retributions. It is only at the moment of nirvÄá¹‡a that it ceases forever.

Because this consciousness is without interruption, it is said that there is mind in the mindless states. The six forms of consciousness are absent in these states and for that reason they are called mindless.

The power of the mind of entrance into samÄdhi, such as the samÄdhi of cessation, etc., temporarily subdues the seeds of the six forms of consciousness and prevents their actual manifestation. For that reason, they are called mindless, but not because all forms of mind are absent.
There are two kinds of mind:
the first is the accumulating mind, because it is the place where innumerable seeds accumulate;
the second is the various kinds of minds, because it evolves in accordance with the differences of the objects and modes of activity of consciousness.
The second kind of mind is absent in states of samÄdhi, and for that reason they are called mindless. They are like a bed with one leg, which is called legless because it lacks the other three legs.

The power of the seeds of the various consciousnesses is suppressed and weakened in the state of samÄdhi, and the consciousness that is retribution is transformed and becomes different. The power of suppression gradually weakens and finally disappears, just as the power of heat that causes water to boil gradually weakens and finally disappears, and just as the power of the arrow that propels it gradually weakens and finally disappears.

When the power of the seeds of consciousness is exhausted, the seeds are able to produce results. First, manas consciousness is born from the seeds of consciousness, and later, in accordance with conditions, the other consciousnesses are gradually produced. The consciousness that is retribution, as mentioned above, contains the seeds of various dharmas.

When the various other consciousnesses and their associated dharmas are frequently activated in a good or bad way, in accordance with the circumstances, the power of the seeds increases. As a result, the continuity of consciousness is transformed and becomes different.
In accordance with the maturity of the power of the seeds and in accordance with the assistance of conditions encountered, one attracts and produces in the future a good or bad result.
In accordance with this theory, there is a verse that says:
The mind, together with its infinite seeds, continues in an uninterrupted stream.
Encountering separate perfuming conditions, the seeds of the mind then increase and flourish.
The power of the seeds gradually matures, and when conditions come together, it produces its fruit.
Just as when a rose apple flower is dyed, the color of the fruit at maturity is red.
The World Honored One, relying on this, in the Mahayana sutra Profound Secrets, spoke this verse:
The alaya consciousness is very deep and subtle, with all seeds like a violent current.
I do not expound it to the ignorant and foolish, fearing they will discriminate and cling to it as a self.
It is called alaya consciousness because it is able to continue future existences and grasp and hold the body.
It is also called alaya consciousness because it stores and conceals the seeds of all dharmas.
It is also called the consciousness of karmic retribution because it is the karmic retribution of actions projected from past lives.
If one does not admit the existence of this consciousness of karmic retribution, then what other consciousness is able to grasp and hold the body?
No other consciousness can universally support the body, because it is never abandoned until the end of life.
Moreover, where in the aggregates is the latent tendency of the passions eliminated when the antidote arises?
If it is said that the aggregates are in the antidote, this is unreasonable. How can the latent tendency of the passions be eliminated by that which is followed by the passions?
Moreover, when sentient beings are born in the formless realms, and when defiled, good, and pure minds are present, what realm do the retribution dharmas belong to?
Or else, you must admit that the realms are common to nonretribution and nonbound dharmas, and that contradicts reason.
Moreover, when nonreturners are born in the highest heaven of the form realm, they cultivate the antidote in order to eliminate the remaining passions.
When the formless realm of nothingness is pure, what other specific thing exists in the highest heaven of the form realm that is not called death, and is not a class member?
Or else, the faculty of life must be a real entity apart from form, mind, etc.
These two are established only hypothetically in the aggregates of retribution in a manner similar to the power of habit.

The power of similarity has no separate substance, just as the power of similarity of rice and barnyard grass has no separate substance. Therefore, it must definitely be admitted that apart from the six consciousnesses there exists a mind that holds the seeds, as explained above.

What is the object and mode of activity of this consciousness?
Its object and mode of activity cannot be known.

Just as those who hold that other consciousnesses exist in samÄdhi of cessation, etc., find it difficult to know its object and mode of activity, so it is with this consciousness.
In which of the aggregates that are grasped is this consciousness included?
In principle, it should be said that it is included in the aggregate of consciousness that is grasped.
If this is so, how can the words of the scripture be understood?
A scripture says,
What is the aggregate of consciousness that is grasped?
It is the six consciousnesses.
Also, it says,

Consciousness is the six consciousnesses.
You should understand that this scripture has a special hidden meaning, as a scripture says:

It is not that there is no other dharma in the aggregate of karmic forces. This is also so.

Because from beginningless time until the end of life, the mode of activity of this consciousness is subtle and does not change.

Also, because the support, objects, mode of activity, and species of the six consciousnesses are gross and easy to know, because they are associated with the passions and the path of opposing them, and because they establish the categories of impurity and purity.
Its substance is the result of consciousness, and from this one infers that there is a consciousness that is a seed.

The scriptures do not mention a cause of consciousness other than the six consciousnesses, because such a cause would contradict the above explanations. This is the hidden meaning of the statement that there are only six consciousnesses.
This explanation also resolves the issue of other schools that maintain that the consciousness that appropriates the body is only the six consciousnesses.

Also, at the present time, innumerable scriptures of all schools have been lost, as is explained in detail in the ÅšÄriputra Abhidharma. Therefore, do not insist that the holy teachings do not definitely mention the Älaya consciousness, because reason definitely proves that it exists.
If this is so, then a single body would have two consciousnesses existing simultaneously, namely, the consciousness that is retribution and the other evolving consciousnesses.
What error is involved in this?
If two consciousnesses exist simultaneously in a single body, then at the same time there would have to be two bodies, just as in the case of two consciousnesses in different bodies.
This is not a mistake, because the two consciousnesses, result and cause, serve as reciprocal supports and do not cease.

Also, the other evolving consciousnesses are perfumed by the store consciousness, and it is impossible for two consciousnesses to evolve simultaneously in the same body. Therefore there is no error in our position.
Is there any case of a seed and its result being seen to be different in a series?

We see in the world that the root of a blue lotus, etc., is different from its stem, etc., and yet the root is the seed of the stem, etc. The same is true of the store consciousness and the evolving consciousnesses.

Also, whether or not you admit that the store consciousness exists, the previously mentioned errors remain. Therefore you must definitely admit that the store consciousness exists as a real entity apart from the six consciousnesses.
Why do you not admit that the real entity of the self is the support of the six consciousnesses?
What is the nature of the self that you hold to be the support of the six consciousnesses?

If you admit that the self is like the store consciousness, that is, that it is born and perishes, that it evolves in a series, and that it transforms according to conditions, then what is it that is different from consciousness that you grasp and hold to be a self?
If you maintain that the substance of the self is one and permanent and absolutely unchanging, how can you say that it is perfumed and becomes the support?

Perfuming causes the supported to change and produce a new power of a different kind, just as the juice of purple lac dye perfumes the flower of the rose wood tree and causes it to change and produce a new power.
If there is no perfuming, there is no change and no new power.
How can you say that the self experiences, cognizes, and desires?
Because of the difference of repeated practice, memory, knowledge, desire, etc., arise differently after a long time.
Moreover, the state of no thought is no different from the self of a later time, and if there is no consciousness at the present, how can mental consciousness, etc., arise later?
Moreover, what power does the self have over consciousness, etc., that you maintain that the self is the support of consciousness, etc.?
If you say that consciousness, etc., are born because of the self, since the substance of the self is always the same, how is it that consciousness, etc., are born gradually and not all at once?
If you say that it must wait for other conditions to assist it in order to produce, then how do you know that the self has the function of producing apart from other conditions?
If you say that consciousness, etc., evolve in dependence on the self, all dharmas are born and immediately perish. Since there is no such thing as duration, how can there be evolution?
Therefore you should not maintain that the substance of the self really exists and is the support of the six sense organs and consciousnesses.

Also, the theory of a self contradicts the scriptures that say that all dharmas are without a self. Therefore your theory of a permanent, real self is totally devoid of sound reasoning and is simply the result of wild imagination.

As a result of this proof, we conclude that only the differences in thought perfuming the Älaya consciousness at the same time cause the continuity of the Älaya to evolve and change, and this in turn attracts future results that are either agreeable or disagreeable. This is not the same as the characteristics of bodily and verbal action as described by the opponent.
If you do not admit that there is bodily and verbal action, how can you avoid the error of rejecting the scriptures that speak of the three actions ?
We do not reject them, but we do offer a rational interpretation of the scriptures that avoids error.
How can we avoid error in explaining this sÅ«tra?

Why does the sÅ«tra speak of three karmas? It is to show that the three karmas encompass the ten karmic paths, and to encourage and inspire those who fear doing too much, just as the Buddha briefly taught the three trainings to the ÅšÄkya clan.
Some hold that all karmas are created only by the body, not by speech or mind. To show that those two also have what is created, it is said that there are three karmas.
The body is the essence of the combination of faculties, elements, and derivatives.
Karma is precisely the nature of the distinctions of volition.
The meaning of body is that which is accumulated, because it is formed by the accumulation of the most subtle particles of the four great elements.
Some say that the meaning of body is that which is formed by the accumulation of various impurities, because the body is the basis of various impure substances.
If that is so, then the heavenly realm should not have a body.
The meaning of karma is that which is created according to the intention of the doer.
Mental volition that can move the body is called bodily action.
There are three kinds of volition:
first, deliberative volition; second, decisive volition; third, initiating volition.
If volition can move the body, it is called bodily action.
This volition can induce the cause for the continuity of the body to arise in a different place, because the wind element arises.

The full expression should be the action of moving the body. Excluding the word moving, it is simply called bodily action, like oil that benefits strength is simply called strength oil, like wind that moves dust is simply called dust wind, this is also like that.
Among the ten karmic paths, the first three karmic paths are said to be included in bodily karma, namely killing, taking what is not given, and sexual misconduct.
How can the karma of volition be given their names?
Because this volitional karma can move the body, causing it to commit killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct.
The power of volition moves the body, causing it to act, and is thus called volitional action, just as the world says that a mad thief burns a village, firewood cooks rice.
How can volition also be called a karmic path?
Volition is called karma because it creates, and it is also called a path because it leads to good and evil destinies, connecting one to rebirth there, and thus it is called a karmic path.
Or, the body that is moved is the karmic path of volitional karma, because the three kinds of volitional karma arise in dependence on it.
Moreover, killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct arise from volitional karma and are born in dependence on the body, and because they follow worldly conventions, they are also called bodily karma.

However, these are really neither good nor bad by nature, and they are also provisionally established according to worldly convention. This is in order to cause the world to rely on these doors and diligently cultivate stopping and doing in regard to good and bad volition. Therefore, good and bad names are provisionally ascribed to them.
If only volition is good or bad, why does the Sutra of the Paths of Action say:
Because of the three kinds of bodily actions, volition creates karma, both doing and increasing, because they are bad and can produce painful results and painful ripening.

The meaning of this sutra is to say that that which moves the body, takes the body as the door, and takes the body as the basis, taking killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct as objects, volition as the cause, and able to attract painful results and painful ripening is called the three kinds of bodily actions, therefore volition creates karma.
Apart from this, the other kinds of volition are called mental actions because they are associated with the mind and are unable to move and emit the body and speech.
If that is so, why does the sutra say:
There are two kinds of actions, namely, the action of volition and the action of having willed.
The first two of the above three kinds of volition are called volition, and the third kind of volition is called volition having been done, and this does not contradict the above passage.
Speech is the nature of sound, and it is called speech because it can express the meaning that one wishes to speak.
The volition that initiates speech is called the action of speech.
Alternatively, speech is the support of syllables, etc., and it is called speech because it can express meaning by means of syllables, etc.
The full expression should be the action of initiating speech, but the word initiating is omitted and it is simply called the action of speech, as in the previous example.
Mind is consciousness, because it can think.
It is called mind because it moves toward other lives and objects.
The volition that moves the mind is called the action of mind, because it causes the mind to create various good and bad things.
The full expression should be the action of the mind, but the word creating is omitted and it is simply called the action of mind.
Or, action associated with thought is called mental action, and action not associated with thought is called mental action, as explained above.

If the three kinds of action have volition as their substance, then at times of distracted thought and thoughtlessness, there is no volition. How can one be said to possess moral precepts or to be immoral?
Because of the nondisappearance of seeds perfumed by the differences in volition, one is said to possess moral precepts or to be immoral. Therefore there is no error.
The differences in volition refer to superior volition that can project the revealing of moral precepts or immorality.

Because of this volition, two kinds of superior seeds are perfumed. On the basis of these two kinds of seeds, as long as they are not destroyed, one provisionally establishes the non revealing of good and evil moral precepts.
When does one say that the seeds perfumed by the differences in volition are destroyed?
It means that after this time, one does not produce volition that is either prohibitive or nonprohibitive of the cause.
According to the precepts previously received, who can destroy these seeds?

That is to say, if there is volition that can give rise to expression, then due to this one abandons good and evil precepts, as well as other causes of abandonment, which are also able to destroy [good and evil precepts].
